author: Primrose Riordan
title: Sharman Stone says quotas for women are needed
text:
Victorian MP Sharman Stone says says female quotas are needed in preselection battles Alex Ellinghausen Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Primrose Riordan A federal Liberal MP, Dr Sharman Stone, has warned of further contraction of the number of women in her party if quotas are not set for pre-selection battles.
Education Minister Christopher Pyne said the party would suffer without more women but maintained he, like Prime Minister Tony Abbott, did not support quotas.
Dr Stone challenged this stance, saying any politician who bemoans the lack of women needed to come forward with a strategy, considering the party has mostly "missed the boat" on channelling more women into the parliament in this round of preselections.
She said there would be no change in the party's make up until there were new party regulations and rules, of which quotas of an equal number of male and female candidates at preselections were a starting point.
"You can't sit back and express your sorrow.
"State by state, we have to agree our preselections will be different, [that] we will require equal numbers in each preselection contest. We will not have a contest until there are women standing there beside the men going for preselection," Dr Stone said.
The comments come as Labor agreed to achieve 50 per cent target for all it's party positions in the next ten years at their national conference in Melbourne.
Mr Abbott's Chief of Staff has also called for more women in preselection battles in June, saying: "our women are not in the safe seats, so when we lose government, we lose our pipeline".
 Speaking on the ABC on Monday night, Education Minister Christopher Pyne said while he did not support quotas, the party needed to give more support to potential female PMs.
"I think we have suffered in the last decade or so in not having enough women in our party room.
"We need to make it a lot easier for younger career-minded women to choose public life, to choose politics and to choose families at the same time," he said.
An internal review of the Victorian Liberal Party found earlier this year that the party needed to establish a code of conduct to prevent bullying and aggressive behaviour towards women, and showed some women were "actively dissuaded" from standing for leadership positions.
Dr Stone said in the last few years she had been approached by party members in her electorate about a few "mildly" suitable men to replace her when she eventually retires, but not once had she been approached about a potential woman candidate.
She also said the rule in the Victorian Liberal party that each branch has to have both a male and female vice president had not been effective.
"This has never translated into more female members of parliament," she said.
There are just two female minsters in Mr Abbott's Cabinet, Foreign Minister Julie Bishop and Health Minister Sussan Ley.
